title-group.subtitle: How School Nurses and Physical Education Teachers Can Combat Childhood Obesity

contrib.aff: Associate Professor, Director, School of Kinesiology, University of Louisiana–Lafayette, Lafayette, LA
Associate Professor, Department Head, and Associate to the Dean, University of Louisiana–Lafayette and Allied Health Professions, Lafayette, LA
Assistant Professor, School of Kinesiology, University of Louisiana–Lafayette, Lafayette, LA

abstract.p: School systems face many challenges in attempting to address the childhood overweight and obesity epidemic. Given the accumulated nature of the required physical activity and the likelihood that only one meal will be delivered while on school grounds, the potential for impactful change in obese or overweight children through school policy is limited. From this vantage point, it is easy to see that physical education programs alone cannot ensure that children participate in 60 minutes of daily physical activity. The necessary multifaceted approach requires opportunities for physical activity to be obtained throughout the school day. The school nurse and physical education teachers are the school personnel most likely to be involved in efforts to curtail the childhood overweight and obesity epidemic at the school level. These individuals are in critical roles of assisting both parents and children when it comes to understanding the devastating effects of being overweight and obese and in helping children identify positive health behaviors that may help reverse this condition. The purpose of this article is to describe the ways in which the school nurse and physical education teacher can work collaboratively to better address the childhood overweight and obesity epidemic.

bio.p: Dr. Bryan holds the Vesta R. Bourgeois Endowed Professorship at the University of Louisiana–Lafayette and serves on several national boards, including the National Association of Girls and Women in Sports and the American Alliance for Health, Physical Education, Recreation, and Dance Research Consortium. Dr. Bryan’s research interests include child/adolescent fitness and physical activity, motivation and motivational climate in physical education, and coordinated school health initiatives.

Dr. Broussard holds the Acadian Ambulance Endowed Professor in Nursing and the Dr. Donald B. Williams/BORSF Professorship in Nursing. She has conducted research on various aspects of school nursing practice. In addition to her faculty role, she works as a school health consultant with the Picard Center for Child Development and Life Long Learning.

Dr. Bellar holds the Patrick Rutherford/BORSF Endowed Professor of Education and is the Director of Human Performance Lab at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette. Dr. Bellar is a certified coach, having completed the United States of America Track and Field Level II course for the sprints, jumps, and endurance events, and is also a certified strength and conditioning specialist.
